text: 750 ml bottle from Jungle Jims in Fairfield Ohio. Clearance for under $5.00 a great bargain! Pours a cloudy amber gold with a white head. Aromas of malt and banana with some orange and herbal Aromas also. Flavor is the same with a little sweetness from the malt. Very complex flavor. Lots of layers of flavor. Light to medium palate. Little lacing in the glass. Nice bitterness at the finish. No alcohol burn at all. Very nice beer.

From a variety pack: pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is quite spicy, fruity, sugary, not boozy. Taste is rather thick, sweet, and spicy. Hefty body. Lingeringn coriander aftertaste. A rather proper tripel.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is bready, spicy yeast esters, citrus, light floral coriander. Taste is crisp and spicy, but also soft. Amazing mouthfeel and just enough character to be special but also very drinkable. Lemon zest, crackers, light pepper, spiced lemon cookies, maybe some peaches. Awesome.

9 Feb 2017, bottle. yellow, faintly hazy. nose is light banana and coriander. med body and mildly fizzy. banana, maybe bubble gum, some bramble, faintly spicy, moderately sweet. Not huge in any area. rather nice.

Pours a bright golden amber with a big white head. Light carbonation with some lacing. Strong aroma of coriander and celery. Fairly smooth with a taste very similar to a Witbier. Lots of coriander flavor and a slightly dry finish. Light sweet bready aftertaste. Not my favorite style. Ok but not great.
Hazy gold color with a large head. Aroma of floral hops and spice. Light coriander. Strong honey, biscuit, and yeast flavor. More coriander. Full bodied. Seems sweetish.

750mL bottle. The aroma has some spicy white pepper character along with some metallic hints and some esters with hints of clove. Hazy golden-orange body with a medium, strong, fizzy white head. Starts with a bit of a bitter, earthy hop character. Some metallic character comes through in the middle before a little sweet lemon takes over. Finishes with a more bitter flavoring. The mouthfeel on this is just exquisite. Really good, if not on the hoppy side...

750 mL bottle. Pours a cloudy orange color with a quick white head. Lots of visible carbonation. Aroma has some sweet fruit, spice and yeast along with a little sourness. Medium body, plenty of carbonation on the tongue. Flavor is a nice combination of malt and yeast producing fruit, spice and a touch of sourness. Finish is sweet and a little sour on the sides. Excellent!
UPDATED: SEP 5, 2016 Yeast and grain heavy aroma and flavor. Clove and pepper with underlying citrus peel. Heavily carbonated with a dry finish. Good.
Aroma of clove, black pepper, oranges, sweet malts, some cracked wheat. Taste is orange and lemon zest, clove, black pepper, and sweet malts, and some cracked wheat.

Poured from bottle into a tulip: Pours clear golden with a one finger white head. Aroma of banana, clove, coriander, little alcohol. Flavor more of the same, lots of pepper, little boozy, but surprisingly dry. Medium body, tasty tripel.

750 ml bottle, shared. Slightly hazed golden pour. Thin sticky white head, good retention, spotty lacing. Sweet honey, cereal grain, some heavier malt. Some yeast in the aroma too, cloves, dough. some lighter herbal hops comes through in the finish. Nice dry finish despite some of the earlier sweetness. Very nice tripel in the end.

May 24, 2016; bomber purchased at the brewery. Heady pour & outstanding aroma. Remarkably peppery, spicy & bitter. Love the Ommegang brews (and tripels) as a rule, but the astringency of this one may take some getting used to. Perhaps because Id just finished a Unibroue La Fin du Monde before cracking this bottle. Would definitely give this another go (and a re-rate).

Pours a bright golden yellow color. Active carbonation throughout the session. Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little yeast. Has a light fruity citrus taste, with some yeasty notes, and a good hop flavor.

Hazed, deep golden color with a smaller, but fairly stable milk colored head. Pale malts, light fruit, touch of floral hops, bit of doughy yeast. Not a strong tripel scent, but a balanced and quite enjoyable sniff. Hope the sweetness is not all in the flavor. Light sweet start. Pale malt and light clover honey. Spices work their way in with light cloves and cinnamon. Hints of herbal hops. Dries out in the finish and the linger is very dry and nearly woody. This is my type of triple. Nice malt base, hops undertones, and mild spice. I actually bought two bottles a number of months ago and the first one, while still good, seems a bit sugary. This has dried out nicely. Very enjoyable. 7/10
Bomber from Benz. Cloudy yellow, small white head. Malty, slight sweetness with a large yeast flavor--some coriander, clove, and banana. More hefe than tripel to my tastes, but solid.

750ml bottle 1/9/16 (Binnys)-42° in Tulip-Pours a cloudy orangish yellow with a big white head. Aroma of yeast, coriander, citrus, and malts. Taste of the same with some grains, grass, spices, and hay coming in as well. This medium to full bodied brew is well balanced and is easy drinking. Great Brew.

750 ml bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Looks solid; a hazy apricot with ample foamy eggshell head and lively carbonation. Smells semi-sweet and bready with notes of pear and Belgian yeast. Tastes like it smells, but more robust, and with some spice as well. Mouthfeel is medium full-bodied. Solid beer.

Approximately half of a 25.4 oz. bottle, consumed on 12-24-15. Yeasty aroma features scents of perfume and golden raisin. Good tripel smell. Smells authentically Belgian, not like a poor American imitation. Pours a cloudy pale with suspended particulate. Highly effervescent. Large amount of fluffy, long-lasting, nearly white head with black speckles. Sugary (brown sugar) taste features a white wine flavor. Excessively sweet. Medium body. Fizzy in the palate. Overall, this is a decent beer. Its generally inoffensive though sweeter than ideal. Unmemorable.
Tripel Perfection is just what I expectedgreat. It pits beautifully and tastes just as smooth as every other beer Ommegang has ever made. Definitely worth buying again.

Hazy orange pour with a thin off white head .... Aroma of oranges, candi sugar, fruity yeast, coriander, light lemon and caramel malts .... Taste is of sweet caramel malts, spicy coriander, orange peel, light lemon, candi sugar, fruity yeast and a spicy bite on the back end as well .... Has a fizzy mouthfeel ... Finishes lightly bitter and spicy ... Well balanced and the abv is hidden well
dough, banana, bubblegum, pale, golden, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, lively, overall very enjoyable

Pours clear golden that shades towards bright golden at the bottom. Buff head is thick and frothy, but effervescent. Yeast, banana, pear and fresh malt comprise the tempting aroma. Flavor presents the same chord as the aroma, satisfying if not spectacular. Mouthfeel has OK fizz and good body. Maybe not perfection, but definitely worthy.

Lemon citrus candy sugar Belgian yeasty aroma. Taste is the same, but not that sweet on the candy sugar. Almost has a slight earthy funk to it. Nice triple overall, but not the best. Maybe the funky spice is the licorice root? Does have much more of a spice than other triples.  The more I drink the more the licorice spiciness comes through.  Not sure if I like that spice in the triple?  Still a well made beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours golden with a nice white lacing. It has fantastic carbonation. Aroma is spices and dried apricots. Sweet taste making one of the best beers Ive tasted. The beer is named appropriately.

11 ounce pour - $10.00 at Taco Mac in Woodstock, Georgia.

Appearance: Deep golden-hued body, lightly hazed beneath a fine, white head.

Smell: A sweetish, perfumy, heavily phenolic bouquet with its boosting spices, some citrus and some addling alcoholic updrafts.

Taste: Honeyed maltiness, lightly bready. Moderate sweetness of blonde syrups. Slightly tangy in taste. Generously phenolic, abundant in clove, coriander and pepper. Bitterish, redolent dried citrus rinds. A little harsh and biting in the booze factor leading to a somewhat sharp finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body, fairly smooth on the tongue. Medium carbonation.

Overall: For me, it fell more than a bit short of its boastful moniker and price-tag.
Pours orange, fluffy and fine white head. Aroma is sweet and yeasty. Tastes of banana, fig, peach, funk, grass. Dry finish and lovely bottle conditioned carbonation. Great, but not perfection IMHO.

This one poured out with a really nice looking yellow gold color. There was a nice hazy to it and a fluffy white head on top as well. The lacing was a little sticky on this one which was pretty nice. The smell of the beer was full of yeasty aromas and some soft spices in the mix. The taste of the beer was was a little tart upfront, nice banana presence, after it warmed it got better. The spices came out a little more and the sweetness of the grains did too. The mouthfeel of this beer was very drinkable, soft and refreshing. Overall I thought this was a really nice Tripel.
On tap at Giant Eagle in Grandview. Scattered note: orange peel, pepper, coriander - spicy finish. belgian yeast, banana, dry. tingly palate. not my favorite style anymore but well done.
Sample at Hopfest 2015. Comes golden brown with a nice off-white head. Aroma of malt, yeast, and citrus. Taste is sweet malt, yeast, citrus, tropical, and spice. Excellent.
Very good Belgian beer. Has a strong flavor to it but it is still pretty smooth. It is a bit cloudy when you pour it. I would recommend it is you like tripels
Perhaps not the perfect tripel but quite tasty. Deep gold with a big off-white head. Yeast, fruit, spice and a touch of honey sweetness.

750 ml bottle. Color is dark gold with lasting head in a snifter. Aroma is sweet grain, citrus and just a bit of the house yeast. 
The flavor shows a sweet grain base with honey notes, apricots skins, Apple and a very mild spice toward the finish. The alcohol is very mild with a slight warming after the sip. The texture has a chewy yeast character with a creamy carbonation level with a mild tingle over the tongue. Ommegang used to be a go-to brewery for me and this beer makes me remember why I liked them so much. A very well executed example of the style and very tasty. I could drink the whole 750 myself.

Pretty nice. Light hint of citrus with good florals and light coriander. Pours hazy rich orange with OK head and lacing. Light sweet finish. Soft carbonation. Palate is lighter than I like in triples but still well balanced and well done. Tap at Scion.
Poured a nice medium clear Amber with minimal head. Slight spice in the mouth with no hint of alcohol. Quite nice.
Gold pour, big off-white head. Aroma of yeast, figs and fruit, fantastic flavor of yeast, dates, figs, fruit, spices, bananas, raisins. Fucking amazing.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Cloudy dark amber color, white head that drops to the rim, tiny lace dots. Taste is fizzy caramel malt with a bit of spice. The runs smoothly through the palate to a finish with a modicum of bittering that keeps all in balance. A solid Belgian.

Very nice beer. Appearance is a long lasting thick off-white head, some lace, and a slightly hazy color. Aroma is yeast, wet grain, malt, spice. Flavor is like nose with carbonic tang up front with a bit of sweet that builds along with the bitter and has a long finish. Clean. Great body. Very easy drinking.

On tap at PNP Charleston. Hazy golden with medium white head. Aroma is golden with medium white head. Aroma is nice banana, medium body, medium/light carbonation, and thick small-bubble lacing. Taste is fruity (mostly banana), some yeast, some alcohol, with a dry finish. Not my kind of tripel.
Tap, amber pour, white head, nose is caramel, taste is sweet, fruity, candy, wow

Hazy amber color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, clove, fruit, & spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, hops, clove, citrus/fruit, and some spice; Nicely balanced; Classic tripel - good!

750 ml. bottled Nov 13, 2014. Pours mostly clear and light amber. Beautifully active body supports an enduring, creamy film of cappuccino-like foam and leaves a perfect cobweb of sticky, sugary lace. Nose is sweet and spicy with flowery honey, white grapes, clove, citrus zest and apple bubblegum. Flavors of dried apricot, pear bubblegum, clove, honey, white wine, citrus zest, wood and a pinch of white pepper. Medium body has a smooth medium-high carbonation and a sweeping spicy-dry finish that balances the front sweetness in fine fashion.

750ml bottle, from Dutchs. Date stamp is difficult to read. ".3/14" ? First part is kind of blurred/stretched out. Enjoyed from a Chimay Goblet. Hazy orange color. Thin off-white / khaki head. Leaves good ridges of lace. Looks pretty good, aside from being a touch darker than Im used to for a tripel. Pours with moderate-plus strength carbonation, but not uncomfortably nor unnecessarily strongly carbonated (like some belgian beers can be). Medium to bigger body, good full feel. Mildly dry finish. Really fantastic big, bright complex fruity flavor. Definitely different than your typical tripel, but its a good thing, much more interesting. Much more of a bright citrus aspect that is really pleasant. Mild spiciness. Banana bread. Seeing the (mild) pear. Nice mild biscuity malt breadiness. Love how this manages to be not too sweet unlike most tripels, the nice mild dry finish is pretty pleasant. Just a moderate sweetness, and a moderate bitterness, with a pleasant very mild warmth at the end. Very easy and pleasant to sip on overall. A fantastic tripel. Better than expected.

Pours a crystal clear golden color with a large white pillowy head. Aroma is herb, clove, malt, apple, pear, yeast, bread, spice, lemon, coriander, bread. Taste is bread, apple, pear, spice, clove, coriander, lemon, orange peel, pepper, herbs, slight honey sweetness, yeast. Overall a good tripel although not my absolute favorite, was expecting slightly more from Ommegang.
Bottle picked out by my wife, pours gold, passes minimal light through, thick off white head. Big mouth of clove, mild biscuit. Full body, mild booze burn.

Pours hazy golden with nice fluffy head. Something seems off here. First impression was buttered popcorn, diacetyl, an off flavor. I get some of the spicy yeast, apple, but I can't get past the buttered popcorn. I love ommegang, I've been to the brewery, but something is definitely wrong here. Batch brewed 11/13/14, bomber.

1/24/2015. 750 ml. corked and caged bottle. Hazy amber with a fluffy white head. Sweet fruit, banana, light spices, honey. Similar flavors, some acidity up front, buttery texture, spices and citrus with a long dry finish.

750 ml bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 11/12/2014. Pours slightly cloudy deep golden color with a 2-3 finger dense and fluffy white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big lemon, orange peel, apricot, pear, apple, banana, coriander, clove, pepper, bubblegum, honey, candi sugar, bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome complexity and balance of fruity/earthy yeast, spices, and pale/bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big lemon, orange peel, apricot, pear, apple, banana, coriander, clove, pepper, bubblegum, honey, candi sugar, bread, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of earthy yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, orange peel, apricot, pear, apple, banana, coriander, clove, pepper, bubblegum, honey, candi sugar, bread, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Incredible complexity and robustness of fruity/earthy yeast, spices, and pale/bready malt flavors; with an awesome crisp malt/yeast/spice balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and slightly prickly/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an absolutely incredible spiced tripel style. All around outstanding balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast, spices, and pale/bready malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink for the ABV. An insanely delicious offering.
A beautiful, nicely rounded triple with hay, bread, a drying finish and a pillow of lush foam atop a richly spiced beer. Really good.

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a thin white head. Soft fruit, wheat, slightly spicy. Medium bodied, candy and wheat. Fruit esters, and a bit of alcohol. Long wheat finish with some light bitterness and a bit more warming alcohol.

On tap at Hops & Pie. Gold and hazy appearance with a white head. Spicy Belgian notes, clove, fruity esters, light banana, rustic yeast and mild bitterness. Medium body with a crisp, dry feel. Overall, nicely done and easy to drink.
Very nice tripel, with dark fruit flavors on the nose. Picking up even more on the first taste. Solid palate all the way through drinking it. Very solid Belgian from Ommegang.

Tap at Butcher and boar and commonmac. Tulip glass. Nice gold pour with thick white head and good lacing. Slightly floral hop and alcohol aroma. Spicy coriander nose, like a saison. Fresh yeast and citrus spice, with sweetness. Nice mouthfeel. Amazing.

Tap at Butcher and the Boar with the commonshawn. Tulip glass. Very attractive pour. Almost a full finger head on a light golden colored tripel. Aroma has some spice elements with an undercurrent of earthy hops smelling similar to other tripels. Taste has a welcomed tartness offsetting an underlying malty sweetness and hop bite. Really smooth and easy to drink with just a touch of alcohol burn at the end. I dont like the word perfection as there is always room for improvement but this is a pretty near perfect effort. Complex and enjoyable. Similar to a Goose Island Sofie.

Hazy deep golden with a large fluffy white head. Wonderful nose of clove and golden toast and pilsner grain and hay and a light belgianesque fruity ester. Nice clovey wheaty flavor with a big boozy pilsner and toast malt tone with a lovely peppery note, a touch of bubblegum and loads of belgian tree fruit yeasty ester. Very lovely tripel.

750ml found on sale for 5.50 - score - I remember a time when that was a fairly regular price for an Ommegang 750 - sigh - those were th days - anyway - pours a hazy gold - the pour is initially rather fizzy, but eventually settles to a thin lace - aroma is fairly sweet baked apple, but wit some rustic phenolics and spiciness to balance - there are also some touches of vanilla, along with underlying notes of banana and clove (which I am not a fan of in my tripels) - moderately frothy texture - flavor is sweet overripe apple and pear, a touch of honey - this is followed by some dusty yeast and spicy/peppery phenolics - some floral bitterness on the tail end, with some lingering vanilla sweetness - not exactly how I like my tripels, but its pretty solid.
750 ml bottle. Straw, hazy golden color dense white head. Spicy citrus nose. Belgian tripel spice bite, candi sugar and hint of alcohol in finish. Clean and to style.
Cloudy amber/orange , huge white head. Aroma of yeast , spices , fruits. Sweet malty taste wit floral , fruity and spicy notes. Light hoppy bitterness in aftertaste. Great tripel from ommegang!

pours a golden orange color with a large thick off white head. Well carbonated with a nice slightly hazy clarity about it.
A nice lemon zest aroma, malts and some earthy spicyness. Clove or banana esters are in there too.
A balanced taste with malts and spiciness but also some sweetness.

Poured into Ommegang glass. Pours beautiful cloudy golden almost peach color. Fruity and bready yeasty aroma with some cloves. Flavor start fruity. A bit of sweet pears and apples. A little bit of pepper bite and some tartness. Spicy yeast in the back with a little tartness. Perfect for a hot summer day.

Tripel Perfection is a good Tripel, but it isnt perfect for me. The spices didnt jump out at me. It lacked a bite and was a bit of a letdown due to the name. All in all, it wasnt terrible, just didnt match my expectation.
Tap. Pours cloudy orange with small white head. Nose is some spice and fruit. Alcohol also comes through. Pear comes through in the flavor with a little bitterness.

Poured hazy golden color with a 2-finger white head. Aroma of orange and spices with a touch of yeast. Medium-to-full body, with a lightly dry finish. Flavor has a touch of licorice up front that gives way to citrus from the orange peel. The coriander shows some in the finish.

Rated on 01-23-2012 (Caged and corked bottle) When poured, the head is medium sized, frothy, very fizzy, and off-white. This beer has a hazy golden body, fizzy, fast rising carbonation, and one ring of lacing. The aroma is malty, floral, sweet, and yeasty. The flavor is sweet, light fruitiness, caramel malt, boozy, and spicy. The mouthfeel is lively and thin. This beer is light-medium bodied. This is a sipping beer with a rather subtle taste for the style which leaves me disappointed as this is one of my favorite beer styles. I was expecting more than what I received which is short on flavor.
Beautiful, fresh aroma of grass and light citrus. Pours a bright but opaque gold. Full bodied belgian with a subtle flavor.

What a great triple. Deep yellow color with huge white thick head. Aroma is crisp and yeast heavy. Big hop and yeast flavors with a nice sweet and peppery finsh. A beer that will run well with the true belgium beers.

25.4 oz bottle. Cloudy orange brown with a white head. Nose is yeast, toffee, orange and bubblegum. Medium body with a sharp buzz. Taste is orange peel, toffee, anise and grass. Cloying sweetness, bitter spices; typical tripel, better than most.
750 mL bottle. Hazy orange yellow pour with a massive frothy off white head. Aroma of citrus, bread and yeast. Medium body with a nice crisp finish.

750 ml. bottle shared, and poured to snifters displaying a hazed, orangey gold color, with a nice layer of silky, white head foam, and strands & spots of lacing. The nose was light yeast, subtle spice, soft malt, and pleasant esters as apricot/peach & lemon. Light bodied, with lively effervescence that was almost fizzy, the taste offered similar notes as the aroma, a soft silkiness to the mouthfeel, and a finish that was lightly dry & crisp. Pleasantly impressive!

750 mL bottle, new label (not the one pictured). Id never had this before. Poured a nice hazy golden color. Had a smell and feel of Saison Dupont, but a bit heavier and less funky. Not sure if it was the same yeast or what. Nice beer.

Pours a hazy yellow-orange with white head. Has a strong yeast and wheat aroma with some lemon. Taste is smooth to start with citrus and wheat flavors, and finishes with grains, malt, spices, and heavy yeast.

Bottle from Julios. Poured into the Ommegang glass that came with the gift pack. Rated from the middle of the bottle. Let it set a while. A hazy medium yellow brew. White head that settles. Better once the carbonation dies down a bit. Strong fruity-spice aromas and flavors. Great yeast profile. Hints of licorice notes. Finish is slightly bready and yeasty bitterness. Good stuff.
Floral and spicy aromas with fruity scents of banana. Hazy gold with a fully lasting white head. Dry, spicy, lightly fruity, and earthy. Medium bodied with refreshing carbonation.
Aromas of clove spice and banana with belgian yeast and some malt. Light white head and rich golden body. Spicy clove and malt with yeasty dry fruit flavor. Spicy dry and smooth on the palate.
Great Belgian yeast, color is wonderfully golden with big perfect white head. Taste outs fantastic, Belgian yeast/banana and grain. Good solid beer!

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange with a frothy white head. Aroma of belgian yeast, bread, orange and citrus. Flavor was slightly sweet with orange zest, citrus fruits, pepper, subtle caramel and a bit of honey.

750 ml bottle poured into stemmed glass. Sparkling golden color with a thick, creamy white head and a tiny but steady stream of rapidly ascending carbonation. Medium intensity Belgian yeast aroma with notes of bubblegum, grass, pear and cheese. Flavor follows suit with some subtle banana notes and a slightly tart finish with some coriander spiciness. Palate is pleasantly dry, as a Tripel should be.
Its a belgiany Belgian full if belgianness. Golden Belgian ale. Pretty standard stuff.

Pours a pastel yellow. A soft golden color like sunshine with a bit of an orange hue when held to the light in the room but with a much brighter lemon color when held to the natural light. A fingers worth of perfect white foam that falls fast but then stays with a ring and film on top. 

Nose is bright with fruit. Tropical fruity twang that hints at pineapple, a soft stone fruit sweetness of apricot and a bright citrus zest. Earthy yeast on the nose give it depth and the malt is a rumor of bread. Mild spice and pepper. 

The taste is elegant and reserved. It is smooth and creamy but has plenty of bubbles to tickle your tongue and enliven the palate to all the flavors. It drinks like a charm. A bit thin and not too sweet with a touch of dryness and a bit of tartness from the fruit. The grain is light in the body of the beer as it warms and adds a supple quality to the drink. There is a touch of alcohol that enhances the fruit sweetness. The aftertaste is long and dry and this has a mild spice and pepper finish that is simply wonderful.

Clove/Banana tones in the first sips that last throughout. A little too gassy that allows the alcohol to seep onto the tongue. Caramel finishes off towards the end. Doesnt have too much of a sweet cloying presence but is heavy at first. A little bitter but that doesnt last too long. Definitely a Tripel.

750 ml bottle into chalice, bottled 3/15/2010. Pours hazy golden orange color with a nice 1-2 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Some nice spotty lacing on the glass, with a decent amount of carbonation streaming up. Aromas of lemon, apricot, pepper, herbal, pear, candi sugar, coriander, bread, and yeast spice. Very nice and balanced aromas; with good strength and complexity. Taste of big lemon, pepper, pear, apricot, biscuit, coriander, herbal, grape, candi sugar, tart grain, and yeast spices. Lightly tart spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, apricot, pear, pepper, coriander, and yeast spices on the finish for a good bit. Great balance of fruity sweetness and spiciness; with no cloying sweetness at all. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a nice fairly creamy and slick mouthfeel as expected for the style. Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly an warming present after the finish. Very smooth to drink, but is still a bit of a sipper. Overall this is a highly excellent Tripel! A lot of great flavor; with nice spicy flavor balance and very smooth to drink. Ommegang needs to make a Tripel year round.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap last April at a private party at Great Divide brewery with homebrew club KROC. pours apricot with big head and lace. Aroma of grassy hops, orange zest, sweet malts, subtle banana. Moderate carbonation and penetrating mouthfeel. Flavors of amber malts, minerals, light powder sugar, subtle chamomile, white grapefruit. Overall relatively smooth and easy drinking with some complexity.
Hazy yellow golden body with a big foamy white head. Nose is sweet spice, bready, belgian yeast. smooth body that is a bit zesty, funky, orange/lemon, sweet Belgian yeast.
Sampled at gabf. From my notes. pours an copper orange with a large white head. orange and lemon zest with a spice finish
Sample at GABF 2013. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Mark a of Belgian yeast, citrus and wheat. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Sample @ GABF 13. Hazy golden pour with a white, small head on top. Aroma is Belgian yeast, bready and touches of fresh apples. Flavour is again yeasty, buttery and typical Belgian. Slight alcoholic kick in the very end. Decent tripel, had better examples.
On draft at the GABF in 2013. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Banana dominates the aroma and flavor. Smooth finish.

750 mL bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a thin frothy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of dry citrus, spice, bready malts, mild nuttiness. The taste is sweet bready malts, tart fruits, yeast, heavy spice, mild hops. Medium bodied, lingering spice. Solid tripel.

Bottle from Wegmans Sterling. Pours light brown with an inch of foam. Not much of anything on the nose.  Very yeasty and bready. Lots of sediment at the bottom. Finishes clean. Solid but not spectacular.

pours a cloudy orange with a medium size off-white head, and good lacing.

smell is of pear, peach, apricot, malt, a touch of caramel, some spice, and yeast.

taste is creamy, sweet fruits, malt, yeast, some hop in the back, and a touch of caramel.  ends on the dry side.

A: Tripel Perfection is a light orange color and appears hazy. A typically large, fluffy, white head is perched atop the beer. The head retention is very good and leaves some quality lacing behind.

S: Citrus, yeast, alcohol, spices. Smells like a tripel.

T: The beer has a lot of flavor, with nice notes of citrus and spice. However, I find it to be a bit too sweet for my liking.

M: Medium body, with a good feel, though again, a bit sweet.

D: An OK beer and a decent example of the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-10-2010

On tap at Southern New Hampshire Brewers Fest. Enjoyed in a 2 ounce glass. dark gold appearance, 1 finger head. Scent is big bready yeast, orange peels, coriander, big orange taste, up front bready yeast. la choufe dryness, figs and lots of citrus. almost a witbier like finish. 20% carb, medium body

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy with a frothy top finely sized off-white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a softly carbonated slightly hazy and a good lacing. The aroma was malty and woody. . The deep flavor contained notes of candy hops and malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Pours a cloudy golden orange, fluffy head which quickly recedes. The aroma is bread, Belgian yeast, apples. Medium to full bodied with high carbonation, giving it a great creamy, even chewy mouthfeel. Flavors of yeast, crackers, apples, honey. Nice crisp hoppy finish, with some fruity esters becoming apparent as it warms. A really nice triple.
 Perfection? No.
 Very Good? Yes.

Bottle: &nbsp Amber, little bit of fireweed honey like hues, moderate sudsy white head, falls quickly, moderate 
carbonation, sparce lacing. &nbsp Expected a bit more head with this one. &nbsp Bready nose, slight cheese, a little barnish, 
some alcohol. &nbsp Sweet maltiness up front, slightly grassy, a little mealy, some alcohol is noticeable. &nbsp Has a cheezy 
backside. &nbsp Not as floral as I would hoped. &nbsp Seems more mealy than floral. &nbsp Not very bright, but at least its

made Tripels.

Aroma: The nose is yeast and spice, with some fruit, floral, and alcohol notes

Bottle/750ml - Pours a slightly hazy amber in color with a small foamy white head that faded to a thin covering over the beer.  Aroma is full of estery fruits, Belgian yeastiness and is slightly sweet.  Flavor is malty with caramel and yeasty with Belgian bread dough.  Light fruits (apple/grapes) present along with some very slight clove/banana.  I like it!!

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Rerate 2013 bottle: it seems a tad less boozy and more traditional than I had in 2011. I like the complex fruit and spice yeast driven character. I will bump up the taste 1 and the overall 1. 

Corked bottle and served in my Big Ole Tripel Karmeliet glass:  Tasted side by side with Two Brothers Oh Brother! Tripel Ale and Straffe Hendrik Brugs Tripelbier 9° App: Slightly hazed amber hue with a lovely frothy head and good lace. 2nd best looking of the three (4) Aroma: Flowery and herbal with some apricot, lemon curd, mint leaves, pepper, moderate alcoholic phenols and earthy yeast esters. A bit weaker than the Straffe Hendrik and more flowery and fruity. (7)  Spicy and aggressive booze strikes you right away with lots of biscuity and caramelized malts. (3) Started strong by the constant abuse of the palate by the sugary palate and brash unruly booze keeps this from becoming a top notch Tripel. It is NOT Perfection by any means. (13)

750 ml bottle purchased over a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($9.99).  Pours a hazy orange-amber hue with two fingers of fizzy white head.  Aroma of grainy bread, dusty malts, spritzy yeast, some fruit, some spice, and a strange salty-fishy smell.  Flavor of light caramel, vanilla, honey, banana, dark fruit, and some spice (clove).  A nice lower level of sweetness with a dry finish.  Pretty good tripel.  (189, 613)

(draft @ Tap and Mallet - Rochester, NY - 2010 vintage) Clear orange pour with a thin white head. Big malty and sweet aroma with some light Belgian spice and yeast. Flavor isnt as sweet as the aroma would lead you to believe. Smooth and malty with a nice and smooth yeast flavor at the finish. Mild bitterness from the spice. Really smooth.

Pours a pale honey/orange with a thick white head...decent lacing.  Aroma is saison like and is a little bit yeasty...clove, bubblegum, delicate hoppiness, hint of alcohol.  Flavor follows suit...not as sweet as some tripels...clove, a bit of black pepper toward the end...also a bit leathery.  Mouthfeel is light and lively and the finish is dry and spicy/peppery.

Simple Ommegang label.  Butterscotch colored pour without much head.  Enjoyably sharp, tangy, yeasty aroma.  This is a fairly sweet tripel - a little brett, some fruit compote - this has a dessert quality to it.  It is not Ommegangs best, but it is a very nice tripel.

Appearance:  hazy, orangey gold with a short, fizzy white head shrinking to a thick collar, with shimmering lace.   Aroma:  spicy/yeasty, with notes of clove, citrus, champagne, and lightly toasted wheat bread.   Taste: orange zest, white grapes, honey, clove, white pepper, crackers.   Finish: smooth, tingly, a little dry, a little sweet, a little herbal.   Notes: Wonderful tripel.  Alcohol almost nonexistent.  Extremely easy drinking and nicely balanced flavors.  Paired perfectly with salad of greens, tart plums, candied nuts, craisins and goat cheese with balsamic vinegar.
Poured orange with nice head smelled very weknowdogs tasted great with a little booze aftertaste really good golden ale

Large format in snifter.  Nice tripple with good straw clear appearence.  Moderatly hopped with a slight citrus.  A little peppery spice and maybe clove?  Nice white lacing after the finger high head worn down.  Moderate carbonation.  Alcohol was not noticed.
Poured a dark golden color with a thick white head. Aromas of bananas, cloves, yeast. Really boozy flavor. Distractingly alcoholic and very heavy.

Bottle @ home. Slightly hazy, yellow orange appearance with a fairly large white head. Bready, citrusy Belgian, yeasty nose. Bready, quite Belgian yeasty, citrusy, light malty flavor. Yeasty, slightly citrusy aftertaste.

Draft at Reds. Poured a lovely hazy medium neon orange color. The head was white with good retention and lacing. Nice smells from this one...mango, subdued clove and white pepper, some pineapple, and a whiff of anise. Medium bodied and sweet. Orange, mango, citrus zest, and white pepper flavors. Delicious.

THOUGHTS: I met the guy whose recipe this probably is. Very nice. My compliments to Wes. Better than most American attempts. It really seemed like it came from Belgium. Hid alcohol fairly well. I only really noticed it in the finish, and even that was only slight.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a light golden with a large, off-white head that mostly diminished and left fair lacing. The aroma had moderate to heavy pale malt and cookie; moderate to heavy spicy yeast; honey and flowers. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and slightly acidic; while the finish was moderately sweet with an average duration. There was pale malt, candi sugar, light caramel, light bread, spicy yeast, ever so slight toast and more yeast. The medium body was a little syrupy and then a bit dry with slightly fizzy, cut rather tingly carbonation and a lightly dry and slightly alcoholic finish.

750 ml bottle that I received as a gift from my friend Paul and was surprised to find that I had not gotten around to rating yet.  Pours a hazy pale gold with a large linen white head that survived to mid-glass and left a layer of foam behind with each successive sip.  Pleasant aroma of citrus, candi sugar, apples and mild spice.  The flavor is similar to the aroma with the same citrus, candi sugar, apples, and mild spice.  Medium bodied and quite effervescent.  I have to admit that Tripel is not my favorite style, but I liked this one better than most.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Translucent medium orange body, thin off-white ring of carbonation. Sweet nose with circus peanuts, pear, white grape, and clove. Body drier than anticipated, dominated by spicy esters (primarily clove, also pepper), with light fruits and circus peanuts. Spicy, bitter finish. Warming. Well-balanced and quite good.
Fra flaske, dufter dejligt af koriander, humle, citrus... flot let grumset gylden med hvidt skum, smager super dejligt af humle, koriander , let spritet eftersmag....... en super dejlig øl !

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a medium white head. The aroma is clove, coriander, sweet fruit and caramel. The flavour is sweet fruity, alcoholic, coriander, oranges and sweet spice. Sweet fruity into the finish.

A - Pours a bright hazy golden-orange color with a big finger of frothy white head. The head hangs around forever, leaving behind lots of lace on the sides of the glass.

S - Aroma is a mix of citrus and spices. There is also some grain, yeast, and banana in the background.

T - The beer starts off with a mix of lemon and some light spices. Through the middle some banana and yeast come through alongside some grain and stronger spices. The finish is a mix of citrus fruits, light spices, and yeast that linger nicely.

M - Medium bodied with moderate lively carbonation. The beer feels super smooth and crisp with a bit of dryness that is really nice.

D - Very drinkable. The flavors are very nicely balanced and fit together very well. Especially the yeast characteristics which feel like they are at just the right level compared to the other flavors.

really nice tripel, and from an american brewery that might as well be from belgium. great color and aroma, typical of a tripel, taste is what youd expect, very easy to drink, the abv is hidden very well, really nice with the pesto pizza i was having with it.

750 c&c. Probably from Monument in Concord some months ago. Pours very hazy gold with a creamy 3 finger white head. Aromas of citrus, stone fruit and yeast/spice. Tap at the Moth. Clear light orange color with a small white ring of head. Very light aroma. Some fruity esters of Belgian yeast and citric orange peel. Flavor is orange cough drops, fruity notes, with a hint of spicy hops. Sweet finish.

Pours hazy golden / orange with a nice sized white head and has very attractive carbonation coming up along the tulip glass.  The aroma has plenty of banana esters, cloves, pale-ish malt, Belgian yeastiness.  Medium body with more crispness than normal for the style and lots of sharp carbonation filling the mouth.  Starts off with lots of spiciness, lots of smooth maltiness, mild esteriness, , pepper and tripel yeast.  The finish is quite spicy and dry for the style.  There is an overall cleanness going on with this as well.  Very enjoyable and well done tripel.
lots of flavor with high quality malts and nice Belgian sugar, very spicy with a strong bite.little hops but the syrup flavors makes this a great beer for the collection

The aroma is very much like a Belgian Ale with lots of yeast, malt, citrus, and spices. The appearance is hazy copper with an average head for the style. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall a well crafted beer without any flaws but also without anything special either.

hazy and deep gold with thick white head.  nose of belgian esters. carbonation low for the style.  low bitterness before belgian esters, predominately tropical fruit and honey.  strong alcohol component that is somewhat distracting.  finish is not as dry as the stronger examples of the style.  overall an average tripel, somewhat disappointing accounting for their claims

Golden, white head, nice lacing. Aroma has a light phenolic character, light pepper, banana. Banana, fruit, pepper, light plastic, digging it. Rounds out well. Could use a tad more carbonation. decent overall.

Shared at the Tampa Crew Tuesday Tasting. Thanks for the share, gunhaver.  Lots of spices and rather sweet. Bold fizzy mouthfeel with a long finish. Enjoyed.

Had this before-but not reviewed. This bottle is part of the Ommegang gift set I bought last week. 750ml bottle poured into my Ommegang flute glass.

A- Body is a slightly hazy golden yellow hue. Pours with a nice 2-3 finger sopay white head that eventually fades to about 1.5 fingers and has perfect retention from there. Bubbles can be seen slowly rising to the top of the glass. Traces of lacing left behind. Cloudiness is uniform. The appearance is exactly what I am looking for in this style.

S- Nose is rather soft. Soft floral hops and moderate green apple scent, and mild peppery spice with a hint of alcohol. The apple is most evident but keeps a nice balance with the other components. Good-and classic for the style.

T- Taste is very mild upfront. Mild floral hops creep in first with an accent of peppery spice and a hint of apple deep in the backbone. The hops and spice intensify as the apple fades and the finish has a sharp (but moderate in strength) floral hop bitterness to it with an accent of alcohol. What is left to linger is a moderate floral hop bitterness, moderate peppery spice, and mild apple wraped in a warm alcohol blanket.

M-High carbonation and a light to medium weight body that is initially smooth and yeasty...then dry. The change in consistency is intersting.

D- This is a great Tripel overall. Not quite "perfection" but just as good if not better than a lot of traditional examples of the style-which this represents nicely. This should be called Fantastic Tripel instead (lol)- another great brew from one of my favorite breweries. Im surprised that this Belgian-style brewery does not have a regular release tripel.

Lot of lush foam in the pour, leave a bunch of lacing and head remains strong, bout half an inch the whole time.  Lots of carbination in this one. (Bottle) Poured light golden color with a large puffy off-white head with excellent lacing. Lemon, spice and yeast in the aroma. Medium body and slight tartness with soft carbonation. A bit of alcohol hotness.

Pour is hazed orangey with a big bubbled (and fast fading) off white head...smell is very perfumey with vanilla, estery yeast, some sweet citrus notes, and cookie dough...taste is malty and mild at first...lots of nice bread and dough flavors...some nice vanilla and caramel flavors along with a hint of pepper and alcohol...lingering finish with a hint of booze...nice chewy mouthfeel...

A solid pour into my Lost Abbey Teku glass produces a fat, three-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head that leaves some spotty lacing as it slowly recedes.  The beer is a pale, orange-gold color that shows a hazed, light straw-gold color when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of lemon zest, earthy coriander like spiciness, a fair amount of clove like phenolics that almost gets musty and medicinal towards the finish.  I really like how floral this beer, it has suggestions of a floral honey, though without the sweetness so it really makes it seem like fresh, flower nectar; notes of honeysuckle intermingles with orange blossom and maybe even a hint of dried grassiness.  This grassiness is also contributed by the light malt character that also supplies notes of pale wheat crackers and a touch of doughy malt; the malt really doesnt start to come out in the nose until the beer warms up.  The aroma of this beer is really quite nice; the complex interplay of spice, floral characteristics, fruit and grain strikes a really great balance and expressive character.

Dry and spritzy with carbonic fizz at it first hits my palate, the beer definitely foams up as it rolls across the tongue and it picks up a perceived sweetness that seems more ester / fruit derived than from lots of residual sugars.  The carbonic character combines with phenols to numb the tongue just a bit and the beer definitely has an ample, though not overly aggressive, flavor of clove in the finish.  Some of the medicinal, almost astringent like notes seems to linger a fair amount in the finish.  The texture of this beer is almost exactly what I want in a Tripel; nicely light bodied, effervescent, but with a nice, softly creamy texture that manages to coat the palate for a short bit without even approaching heavy.  The malt character here is actually quite subtle; it contributes perhaps a touch of honey like character, a touch of faint grassiness and a hint of cracker like malt that lingers a bit in the finish.  The beer can be a bit phenolic in the finish at times (especially as it warms), though I think much of this is accentuated by the fact that this has such a nice, light body to it such that it isnt masked by a sticky sweetness.

The aroma of this beer is quite heavenly; though the flavor doesnt quite live up to this beginning this is still a really nice example of a Tripel.  I really like how this achieves the texture and lightness that a really good example of a Tripel should.  As the beer warms up it gets closer to having a flavor more reminiscent of the aroma (with lots of citrus and floral notes), but it still has that almost harsh, phenolic finish.

Bottle. Poured cloudy yellow color with a large frothy off-white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Complex citrus, spice and yeast aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy citrus & spice flavor with a medium to heavy spicy sweet finish of moderate duration with a small alcohol bite. This is a refreshing standout beer.
Nice dark pouring beer. Nice head retention. Very smooth and drinkable beer.

Pours dirty gold with a surprisingly moderate head that fades to a small ring over time.  Aroma has a lot going on with hay, dirt, toast, chardonnay, spice (cant specifiy really), and a certain dustiness.  Aroma wasnt has loud as I hoped for. Aftertaste becomes a little tangy if you dont take another sip for a minute or so.  Medium-full bodied, high carbonation, good creamy body, a good mix of elegance and chewiness.  Although I wish the aftertaste was a little different, the beer is quite enjoyable and has lot for fans of tripels to enjoy.

dark gold pour with a thick frothy white head.
aroma is lemony, pale fruits and spice tones, some wheat like tones. 
flavour is fruity. pear and apricot, cardamom and clove like spice. Some tartness, something mineraly in the finish for me.
